doc.title: Epic Technical Specification: Foundation & Infrastructure Setup
doc.snippet: Epic 1 establishes the foundational infrastructure for the AI enhancement platform, delivering a complete local development environment and production-ready deployment configuration. This epic builds the technical foundation upon which all subsequent features will be constructed.

doc.title: Epic Technical Specification: Foundation & Infrastructure Setup
doc.snippet: Core Technologies: Python 3.12 with FastAPI 0.104+, PostgreSQL 17 with SQLAlchemy 2.0+, Redis 7.x as message broker, Celery 5.x for distributed task processing, Docker and Kubernetes 1.28+ for deployment.

doc.title: AI Agents - Decision Architecture
doc.snippet: Multi-tenant AI-powered ticket enhancement platform built with FastAPI, LangGraph, and Kubernetes. Uses Redis as message broker with Celery workers to process ServiceDesk Plus webhooks asynchronously. Key architectural decisions prioritize production readiness, multi-tenant isolation, observability, and AI agent implementation consistency.

doc.title: AI Agents - Decision Architecture
doc.snippet: Backend: FastAPI 0.104+, Pydantic 2.x, Uvicorn. Database: PostgreSQL 17, SQLAlchemy 2.0+, Alembic. Message Queue: Redis 7.x, Celery 5.x. Development Tools: Black, Ruff, Mypy, Pytest. Infrastructure: Docker, Kubernetes 1.28+, Gunicorn + Uvicorn workers.

doc.title: Kubernetes Deployment Guide
doc.snippet: Required tools: kubectl (v1.28+), Docker. Local Kubernetes options: Minikube (recommended for macOS/Linux), Kind (recommended for Linux), or cloud providers (AWS EKS, Google GKE, Azure AKS).

doc.title: Kubernetes Deployment Guide
doc.snippet: Deploy all components with automated validation using ./k8s/test-deployment.sh script. Creates namespace, ConfigMap, Secrets, PostgreSQL StatefulSet, Redis StatefulSet, API Deployment, and Worker Deployment.

doc.title: AI Agents
doc.snippet: Python 3.12+ (required for all dependencies), Docker Desktop (for running PostgreSQL and Redis locally), Git (for version control).

doc.title: AI Agents
doc.snippet: Four-step setup: Clone repository, create virtual environment with Python 3.12, install dependencies with pip install -e ".[dev]", configure .env file with database and Redis connection strings.

doc.title: AI Agents
doc.snippet: Docker configuration runs complete stack locally. Quick start: copy .env.example, run docker-compose up -d, wait for health checks. Access API at http://localhost:8000 with documentation at /docs endpoint.

doc.title: Environment Variable Template
doc.snippet: Defines AI_AGENTS_DATABASE_URL, AI_AGENTS_REDIS_URL, AI_AGENTS_CELERY_BROKER_URL, AI_AGENTS_ENVIRONMENT, AI_AGENTS_LOG_LEVEL. Default values configured for Docker service names (postgres, redis).

constraints.constraint: All documentation must reference project-relative paths (not absolute paths)
Code examples must be syntactically correct and tested in development environment
Environment variables must use AI_AGENTS_ prefix consistently (defined in src/config.py)
Documentation must support three deployment modes: local (no Docker), Docker Compose, and Kubernetes
Setup time target is <30 minutes for new developers following README (AC #7)
Code quality standards: PEP8 compliance, Black formatting, Ruff linting, Mypy type checking (from CI/CD pipeline)
Testing requirements: Pytest framework, pytest-asyncio for async tests, 80% coverage minimum (from tech spec)
Contributing guidelines must document: branch naming (feature/, bugfix/, docs/), PR process, code review requirements
Troubleshooting sections must include: symptoms, causes, solutions, and debugging commands
All external links must be validated and point to official/authoritative sources
Architecture documentation must align with decisions in docs/architecture.md
Deployment documentation must cover both local (Minikube/Kind) and cloud (EKS/GKE/AKS) clusters

tests.standards: Testing framework: Pytest >=7.4.3 with pytest-asyncio >=0.21.1 for async test support. Test configuration in pyproject.toml defines asyncio_mode=auto, testpaths=[tests], with markers for slow and asyncio tests. All tests follow naming convention test_*.py with test functions prefixed test_. Shared fixtures in tests/conftest.py provide environment setup and configuration. Coverage target: 80% minimum (from tech spec). Test separation: unit tests for isolated logic, integration tests for component interaction. CI/CD pipeline runs: Black formatting check, Ruff linting, Mypy type checking, and Pytest with coverage reporting. For documentation testing: primarily manual verification tests including README walkthrough (timed to <30 minutes), link validation, command syntax verification, and cross-reference validation.

locations.note: Documentation testing is primarily manual validation following Testing Strategy in story Dev Notes
